Here are three examples to illustrate the quote:

1. Understanding Idioms and Proverbs: Idioms and proverbs are expressions used in everyday speech that have a deeper cultural meaning. For example, the English idiom "to beat around the bush" means to avoid discussing the main issue, while the Spanish idiom "dar una vuelta al sol" (to turn around the sun) means to waste time. To understand the full meaning of these expressions, one must have a deeper understanding of the cultural values, beliefs, and attitudes of the people who use them.
2. Cultural Context in Literature: The cultural context in which a piece of literature was written can greatly impact its meaning. For example, Chinua Achebe's "Things Fall Apart" is a novel set in colonial Nigeria that explores the cultural values and beliefs of the Igbo people. To fully grasp the meaning of the book, one must have an understanding of the cultural context in which it was written.
3. Nonverbal Communication: Nonverbal communication is an important aspect of language that is often a reflection of cultural values, beliefs, and attitudes. For example, in many Western cultures, direct eye contact is considered a sign of confidence and honesty, while in some Asian cultures, avoiding eye contact is a sign of respect. To understand the full meaning of nonverbal communication in a given culture, one must have a deeper understanding of the cultural context in which it is used.
